title: Acceleration of a leaking bucket and counterweight

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students set up the Atwood machine shown in the figure above, which consists of a light string passing over a pulley whose mass and friction are negligible. A counterweight of constant mass is connected to the right end of the string. A bucket full of water is connected to the left end of the string. The counterweight has a mass less than that of the full bucket, but greater than that of the empty bucket. At the same time, water begins to flow out of the bucket through a hole on the side near the bottom. The graph above shows the acceleration of the counterweight above its initial position as a function of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals 1.2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, where positive acceleration represents upward acceleration for the counterweight. The bucket and counterweight continue moving long after this time. (a) At what time is the mass of the bucket and water equal to the mass of the counterweight? Explain your reasoning.

The graph above shows the acceleration of the counterweight above its initial position as a function of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals 1.2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, where positive acceleration represents upward acceleration for the counterweight. (b) At what time does the counterweight reach its maximum height? Justify your answer.

The students model the velocity of the counterweight using the function <math alttext="v of t, equals 1.2, t minus 1.5, t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> for the time interval <math alttext="0 seconds is less than t, which is less than 1.2 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Note that positive velocity represents upward velocity for the counterweight.(c) Is it plausible that this function could correctly model the velocity during this interval? Why or why not?
(d) Explain why this function does NOT correctly model the velocity of the counterweight over a long period of time, assuming that the system is able to move for a long time.

The students are told that the counterweight’s mass <math alttext="15 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is and the mass of the bucket with water in it is approximately given by the equation <math alttext="M of t equals, open parenthesis, 1.28, t squared, minus 9.34, t, plus 18.65, close parenthesis, kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>1.28</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9.34</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>18.65</mn><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t is less than or equal to 3.5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students also know the initial heights of the bucket and the counterweight above the ground. Assume any action-reaction forces between the bucket and the water draining are negligible.(e) Explain how the students could use this information along with the velocity function <math alttext="v of t, equals 1.2, t minus 1.5, t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to calculate the total mechanical energy of the system consisting of the bucket, the water in the bucket, the Earth, and the counterweight at time <math alttext="t equals 1.2 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
